titlestmt.titleproper: BU Records: Baylor Historical Society, Inclusive: 1883-1982, Bulk: 1883-1981

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Records Summary
did.abstract: BU Records: Baylor Historical Society consist of manuscripts generated by the society and a few people outside the society. The records contain correspondence, financial papers, literary productions, and legal materials.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Baylor Historical Society, formed to “stimulate interest in the history of Baylor University,” began in February 1941. Membership was open to anyone interested, and it only cost $1 to join the society.

Though the society was interested in Baylor history in general, members were especially interested in the Texas Collection and Independence, Texas. Since the Texas Collection was the designated repository for Texas history-related items, members directed donations there of original trustee minutes from Baylor’s early history, four dresses from Baylor presidents’ wives, and the collection of William Carey Crane, a former Baylor president. Baylor University started originally in Independence, Texas, and the society was very interested in preserving Baylor’s history there. Members raised money to stabilize the iconic Baylor columns, drew up plans to reconstruct a dorm and operate it as an inn, and lobbied the Texas Legislature to adopt part of Independence as a state park.

Through the 1950s and 1960s, the group raised money to do what they could. Members also helped the Texas State Garden Club landscape around Independence. The society also held regular meetings and luncheons on the Baylor campus, and usually heard a historical paper given at each meeting. The collection contains all known papers read at the yearly meetings.

Though technically not attached to the university in any way, so many employees from Baylor were members of the society that the group enjoyed semi-official status on campus. State luminaries such as Price Daniel and Pat Neff read historical papers to the group, longtime staff members P.D. Browne, Robert L. Reid, Lilly Russell, and E. Bruce Thompson served as officers, and many ancestors of early Baylor-associated families were members.

The Society’s contributions to Baylor and Texas history are many. The time that they operated in Independence is especially significant, since it had been thought Baylor was not active in Independence in the 1940s-1960s. Instead, this society was very active at raising money for the columns at Independence and bringing donations to the Texas Collection.

It is not known when or why the society disbanded. In 1957 the society spent most of their annual meeting taking suggestions from members on how they could improve their organization, indicating that they were not as focused as they had been in the past. Though the society had been formed as a research institution, many members were in favor of reforming the society around other goals. By 1964, the society only had 21 members at their annual meeting, and many of the people who had taken the lead in forming and running the organization had passed away. Longtime member P.D. Browne donated the society’s records to the Texas Collection in 1975, even though some financial papers in the collection have a 1982 date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: BU Records: Baylor Historical Society begins in 1883 with copies of Baylor Trustee minutes, and goes to 1982 with budget statements. The bulk of the collection is between 1940 and 1960, when the society was most active trying to raise money to restore the Baylor columns in Independence, among other projects. Documents include a large amount of correspondence, legal documents, financial papers, and literary productions. The correspondence series is by far the largest series in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, about half of the Baylor Historical Society records were organized very loosely by year, with the rest completely unorganized. Currently, the records are arranged in four series: I. Correspondence, II. Legal Documents, III. Financial Documents, and IV. Literary Productions.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: BU Records: Baylor Historical Society Records, Accession #BU/28, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Paul T. Fisher. Released on 2013-06-17.

Archivist''s Notes: This collection has a significant amount of information on Baylor’s activities both official and unofficial in Independence during the 1940s to 1960s. This period was once considered to be a time when Baylor “abandoned” Independence, but there was in fact activity by many Baylor people in Independence during that time, as proved by these records.

The Essays and Speeches distinctions in the literary series were made because the speeches were in fact spoken to the members of the society during their meetings. The speeches were known to have been spoken during societal functions. The essays have not been proven to have been spoken, and some were probably written only to answer specific questions members had, not to be scholarly papers like the speeches. The speeches are organized by the last name of the author.

Membership mailing lists differ from membership lists in that the names on both do not match exactly. Perhaps the mailing lists were for members who were farther away than the majority of the members on the membership lists.

“Luncheon” references refer to the annual lunches that the society held, usually in the Bill Daniel Student Center. A scholarly historical paper was usually presented at these lunches, with some connection to an important Baylor figure or event. These are the speeches mentioned above.
The research cards at the end of the literary series were Professor P.D. Browne’s notes about collections the Texas Collection had acquired on important Baylor figures.
